Time domain feature calculation

Source: R/feature_calculation.R
calculate_feature_time.Rd

calculate_feature_time calculates accelerometer data into time domain mathemetical features.

calculate_feature_time(df_raw = NULL, winlen_dba, axis_num = 3)

Arguments

df_raw

A data.frame or tibble contains raw accelerometer data. In this version, it should be arranged as x,y,z,x,y,z,...,label for each row and all rows should have the same length.For dual-axial accelerometer data, it should be arranged as x,y,x,y,...,label. And for single-axial, it's arranged as x,x,..., label.
winlen_dba

An integer scalar defining the length of running window for ODBA calculation. It is suggested that the length be derived over a period of no less than 1 stroke cycle. See Shepard et al. 2008 doi:10.3354/ab00104.
axis_num

An integer scalar indicating number of axis in the dataset.

Value

A data.frame contains all caculated time domain features with 19 variables (columns) named x_mean, y_mean, z_mean, x_variance, y_variance, z_variance, x_sd, y_sd, z_sd, x_max, y_max, z_max, x_min, y_min, z_min, x_range, y_range, z_range, ODBA. The cases (rows) in the returned data.frame equal to the cases of df_raw. For dual-axial accelerometer data, the returned data.frame will contain columns start with character "x" and "y", as well as ODBA. For single-axis, the returned data.frame will contain columns start with character "x" as well as ODBA.

Details

Please see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feature_engineering for the definition of feature engineering or feature extraction. In this function, basic time domain features were calculated including: mean, variance, standard deviation, max, min, range and ODBA. These features are calculated for each segment and each ACC axis separately (denoted with prefix x,y,z), except for ODBA, which is calculated using all available axes. ODBA is short for Overall Dynamic Body Acceleration. This value was proved to be correlated with animal energy expenditure in many studies, see Wilson et al. 2006 doi: 10.1111/j.1365-2656.2006.01127.x for more details. Here, ODBA were calculated into mean value of the behaviour segementation. Note that this function doesn't give inclusive calculations of all potentially valuable time domain features and since it is asserted that feature engineering plays an important part of machine learning model's success, more customized features could also be calculated by users. A review reference - Brown et al. 2013 doi:10.1186/2050-3385-1-20 - provides more potential features. One could also reference feature engineering for human wearable devices which partly use tri-axial accelerometer data since this is also a popular research and commercialized field.

It is recommended to input sorted acclerometer data by order_acc.

Examples

data(whitestork_acc)
whitestork_acc_sorted <- order_acc(whitestork_acc)
df_time <- calculate_feature_time(df_raw = whitestork_acc_sorted, winlen_dba = 11)

#> Warning: Suggestion: transform raw data into 1g = 9.8 m/s2 for consistency
df_time_1d <- calculate_feature_time(df_raw = whitestork_acc_sorted[, seq(3, 121, by = 3)],
                         winlen_dba = 11, axis_num = 1) #example for single-axial ACC

#> Warning: This function expect the input data sorted by function order_acc.
#> Warning: Suggestion: transform raw data into 1g = 9.8 m/s2 for consistency
df_time_2d <- calculate_feature_time(df_raw = whitestork_acc_sorted[, -seq(1, 120, by = 3)],
                         winlen_dba = 11, axis_num = 2) #example for dual-axial ACC

#> Warning: Suggestion: transform raw data into 1g = 9.8 m/s2 for consistency
